results.abstract: AAR, citing Penn Central bankruptcy, says Fed Govt must come up with over $1-billion a yr in new ry subsidies or face 'ever increasing number of bankruptcies'; describes appeal as 'very conservative estimate' of pub share of $36-billion in projected capital investment over next decade; says most of subsidies would be repaid in taxes on revitalized rail indus; sees Nixon legis proposing $750-million in loan guarantees to nation's rrs as only '1st step' toward recovery; backs fundamental reorgn of regulatory principles and orgns; former Sen Smathers maintains rail network is intimately connected with health and growth of econ; holds problems of rrs can be traced to Govt favoritism towards other modes and constraints Govt has imposed on rr indus; assn recommendations detailed

headline.main: O'Herron Sees Payrolls Assured, but Gorman Is Gloomy on Survival; RAIL ASSOCIATION URGES SUBSIDIES

results.snippet: WASHINGTON, June 30 The Penn Central Transportation Company closed its books last night with approximately $35-million in its depository banks and expects no problem with its payrolls of $20million a week "for the foreseeable future." This...

byline.original: By ROBERT E. BEDINGFIELD Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 30 The Penn Central Transportation Company closed its books last night with approximately $35-million in its depository banks and expects no problem with its payrolls of $20million a week "for the foreseeable future." This reassurance was given Congress today by the company's executive vice president for finance, Jonathan O'Herron.

results.abstract: NASA officials announce details of $2-billion Skylab project, in which 130,000-lb earth-orbiting space lab will be launched in '72, news briefing, Marshall Space Flight Center; project dir Schneider expresses confidence craft will be launched on schedule; project, formerly known as Apollo Applications program, will use modified Saturn rockets and Apollo spacecraft; lab will be built out of empty 3d stage of Saturn 5 rocket and astronauts will ferry to and from it in slightly modified Apollo spacecraft; docking adapter, airlock and telescope module, which will be attached to front of lab, will be only new parts; adapter and airlock will contain communications systems and control panels and serve as connecting link between lab and Apollo command module; astronaut W Cunningham, who has worked on project since '68 and is likely to lead 1 of 1st crews, says project will be most elaborate US effort to gather biomedical data on long-term effects of weightlessness on human body; says scientist-astronauts will get flights; all astronauts will learn how to operate such attachments as telescope; 48-ft-long lab will orbit earth for 8 mos; three 3-man missions are planned; Schneider says astronauts on 1st mission will study physiological and psychological effects of flight, 2d mission will be devoted primarily to operating telescopes and 3d crew will stress survey of earth's resources with highly sensitive cameras; 1st flight will last 28 days, 2d and 3d 56 days; flight plan detailed; lab will have 3 times as much room as Apollo command module and be divided into 2 floors; artist's conception of Skylab in earth orbit; schematic diagram of crew's qrs

headline.main: NASA TOPREPARE 'BRIDGE' TO MARS; Earth Orbiting Laboratory Viewed as Forerunner of Long Space Voyages NASA Prepares 'Bridge' to Long Voyages

results.snippet: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., July 1 After years as Apollo's poor relation, an old project with the new name Skylab has taken moonflight hand-me-downs and come up with a roomy orbiting workshop that is expected to catapult the United States into an era of space...

byline.original: By JOHH NOBLE WILFORD Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., July 1 After years as Apollo's poor relation, an old project with the new name Skylab has taken moonflight hand-me-downs and come up with a roomy orbiting workshop that is expected to catapult the United States into an era of space voyages lasting months and even years.

results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 4 Thousands of persons of various political persuasions turned out here today for Honor America Day and, in Fourth of July pageantry and confrontation, expressed both the divisions and the promises of the United States on its 194th birthday.

headline.main: A Year Later: Apollo's Message; A Year Later: Armstrong Reflects on Moon Landing

results.snippet: The world and Neil A. Armstrong have had a year to reflect on his "giant leap," the first human step on the moon. Neither can quite comprehend the ultimate meaning of that dramatic event on July 20, 1969.
results.lead_paragraph: The world and Neil A. Armstrong have had a year to reflect on his "giant leap," the first human step on the moon. Neither can quite comprehend the ultimate meaning of that dramatic event on July 20, 1969.

headline.main: NASA Foresees Dynamic Program Despite Budget Cut

results.snippet: From the time men first walked on the moon a year ago today, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has been struggling to define and win public support for an ambitious range of post-Apollo projects and goals. The struggle is now reaching...
results.lead_paragraph: From the time men first walked on the moon a year ago today, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has been struggling to define and win public support for an ambitious range of post-Apollo projects and goals. The struggle is now reaching a critical time of decision.
